Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: High Pulse Energy Mid-IR Vertical External Cavity Surface Emitting Lasers (VECSELs)
Award.AbstractNarration:
This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project will address the need for high pulse energy laser sources operating in the mid-infrared (mid-IR) spectral region. Currently available lasers sources are limited in their capabilities. Wavelength selection and maximum output powers are limited, and efficiency, reliability and costs are also issues. High-power vertical external cavity surface emitting laser (VECSEL) development which employs multiple chip arrangements has the potential to reach wavelengths that are not easily attainable in a very compact package. In addition, the introduction of multiple gain elements inside the laser cavity provides a means for power scaling and extreme broadband mid-IR laser tuning. This also makes it possible to improve upon the conversion efficiency of other parametric oscillator laser sources. Using a high power doubly-resonant two-color T-cavity VECSEL, efficient difference frequency conversion will be achieved. High pulse energy in the mid-IR spectral region will be demonstrated through a novel design in which one of the VECSEL chips will be pulsed while operating the second color under continuous wave operation.

The broader impact/commercial potential of this project is wide ranging due to the flexibility of the design. The goal of the proposed work is an innovative approach to the development of a new class of high pulse energy laser sources at wavelengths that are currently difficult to achieve. In addition to the application rich mid-IR, the laser design can easily be extended to other wavelengths in the far-IR, THz, visible, and UV portions of the spectrum. The approach can have a significant impact in various fields of science and engineering. The discoveries made within the scope of this program will have a transformative impact in mid- to far-IR lasers and benefit a number of disciplines including: laser surgery, dental surgery, dermatology, atmospheric monitoring, chemical sensing, and a broad range of defense applications including LADAR and laser range finding. In addition to the technological impact, the proposed research will cover multiple disciplines in science and engineering including high energy material properties, semiconductor physics, nonlinear optics and laser physics which will provide a unique research opportunity.

POR.DRECONTENT:
For the SBIR Phase I award, High Pulse Energy Mid-IR Vertical External Cavity Surface Emitting Lasers (VECSELs), TPhotonics Inc. identified four main objectives. Demonstrate a pulsed single chip VECSEL, demonstration of mid-IR outputs in the 5-7µm range, demonstrate pulsed mid-IR outputs, and complete a system simulation for power scaling capabilities.   Even though significant difficulties occurred due to the delivery of parts which were not manufactured to our specifications, the project saw several significant results. In fact all of the major milestones were achieved as well as some additional results including: pulsed single chip operation (tunable), pulsed sum frequency generation (SFG), extracavity mid-IR generation, intracavity mid-IR generation, and simulation of the power scaling potential of the device.

During the phase I effort we obtained all of the key objectives for the project, but were limited in some of our measurements due to manufacturing errors in some of our components. Through this SBIR we also showed for the first time DFG in a t-cavity VECSEL and a output wavelength of ~5.6um was obtained which is in the 5-7um we were targeting. Furthermore, the measurements on the fundamental output power while the AGS crystal is inside the cavity indicates power scaling of the circulating power is scalable with pumping levels as well as through increased pump area. Some of the main results are as follows:

Demonstration of a pulsed single chip VECSEL. This was done for both the 980nm and 1180nm samples. Figure 1 shows the gain switched pulse of the 980nm sample (in yellow). In addition, this figure also shows the SFG pulse (in green) generated in the full t-cavity configuration. The sample was tunable by the rotation of the included intracavity birefringent filter.

Demonstration of mid-IR generation via intracavity difference frequency generation in a t-cavity VECSEL configuration. An AgGaS2 (AGS) nonlinear crystal was used and the output measured was at ~5.6um which is in the 5-7um we were targeting. Figure 2 shows the t-cavity configuration, and figure 3 shows the mid-IR spectrum. The output power was limited due to errors in the cut of the nonlinear crystal.

Pulsed mid-IR operation – the pulses of the mid-IR output were not able to be characterized due to the low power output, but the detection scheme used required pulsed inputs. Thus by chopping one of the VECSEL cavities the detector was able to measure the pulsed mid-IR frequency in the 5.6um range. This was indirect confirmation of the pulsed behavior of the generated mid-IR.

System simulations were set-up based on the SFG and DFG data collected in order to judge the power scaling capabilities of the device. The well understood lithium triborate (LBO) crystal used for SFG typically sees a reduction in circulating power by ~50% when the crystal is inserted into the cavity. The AGS crystal saw a larger reduction in circulating power (~60%) but indicates the intracavity losses associated with the crystal will not prevent power scaling of the mid-IR outputs. We also used the crystal in two different t-cavity arrangements; one with a ~380um pump spot diameter, and another with a 450um pump spot diameter and confirmed that there was an increase in circulating power with the larger pump diameter. This further reiterated that power scaling is possible not only by pumping the sample harder, but also through the traditional means of increasing the gain area on the chip.
